response.message: At lest someone in this industry knows how it has to be done...

Seeing SE's ideals and their awesome offices just reminds me how depressed I am that I'm in a drab, micro-cubicle with two walls and coworkers who seem to have non-stop phone conversations all day long. I don't have the CV to get hired at SE, else I'd already be there.

As I work on a consulting company, I switch clients frequently. They almost all have abandoned even the slightest separation of employees. 

The fun(ny) part is that no employee thinks its better. Most of us use a headphone to concentrate in a noisy and messy environment (how I wish I could share a photo with you guys).

Open plans seems to me a way to squeeze more employees in less space. Contradictory to the notion that you probably only need more employees because they aren't productive given the hard time they have concentrating and the time they waste chatting to each other (If I remove my headphone I'm sure I can listen to at least one chat about bs instead of work stuff).

TL;DR I'd give an arm to work for you guys. Or, better yet, a leg, so I can still write code efficiently.

We do have offices, but there are 4-5 engineers per office. Back when I was an undergraduate, I interviewed for an internship at one company with an open floor plan. It was weird. I can't imagine working there. Being pretty much the stereotypical geek, I greatly value privacy and being left alone to do my work. I don't mind meetings to hash out designs and what needs to be done, but when I'm actually coding, I greatly prefer to be left alone.

I used to program in a two-person office with a door. Often our hours were a bit non-overlapping. I brought discarded cubicle panels in and stacked them around the walls and between us - it was quiet as a tomb in there. People walked in and the silence took their breath away. I put a non-functional "doorbell" panel with our names on it in the hallway as a gag, people fell for it, haw haw. 

Now I am an instructor, so I sit in class in front of my students all day, but the environmental people raised all their monitors so high that I cannot see them (mine is still down where it is supposed to be, and yes, I use a wrist-rest and my keyboard legs are down).

I think there's something to be said for both privacy and an open work environment.  In my company, there isn't anything separating us except for 5-10 feet of space.  When I started, I wasn't too keen on it but I've gotten used to it and actually prefer being around my co-workers to the isolation of a private office.

There just isn't a clear answer on this issue and it depends on the chemistry of a department.  We all get along very well in my department, but one with a toxic chemistry can end up disastrous without some form of separation, yet good employees can feel distant and demoralized without the reinforcement of social interaction within a team.  It's said that a lack of separation leads to wasted time chatting, yet it can also be said that too much separation can lead to a loss of productivity if people are less-inclined to put their heads together to solve an issue.

Personally, I'd rather work in a place where I feel like a part of something I can care about as opposed to a cog in a machine.  Even if I hate a company, feeling comfortable among a group of people can make every day tolerable and even enjoyable.  One of the reasons I own a home is so that I can have a private place to myself; I don't need a level of privacy even close to that at work, and for the most part I think that someone feeling like they need that level of isolation can be a sign that they don't enjoy their job(and aren't in a mindset where they could be as productive).  I'm not saying that this is always the case, but it's my guess from looking at my own experience.  I just can't see why a whole team of developers would even need so much as an office for each person.  Perhaps one for the technical director or sysadmin, but not for every developer.  Again, whatever works for whatever team chemistry.  This opinion comes from a lowly employee.

I worked for Taligent (the Apple / IBM / HP joint venture) when they were building out their new office buildings. The Facilities folks did the math and went with private offices over cubicles (this was back when "open plan" meant the stock exchange or a call center).  Only one team got low-walled cubicles - a design team that claimed they needed to be able to call to each other around the space. They were also housed in a small wing of their own, away from everyone else.

My own door. My own light switch! It may have been 8' x 10' but it was the best office space I've ever had.

Open plans can work. They need:
- correct acoustic setup (i.e. prevent train station feel)
- privacy
- conference rooms for longer meetings
- "libraries" where people can withdraw to for silent time

Done right, this is much more expensive than individual offices, which is why most exploiters ... erm, employers ... don't do them right, but instead cramp 50 people in one room and call that an open plan.

And obviously open plans are suited best for creative positions and/or those where collaboration and team-switching are frequent.

They are not suited for typical office work, where each employee is an island and five people are talking on the phone at any given time.
How can you tell a New Yorker?  They think being in a tall office building, and being able to see lots of other tall office buildings, is a "view".  :-)

I worked at a company doing analytical work and doing training/installation work for groups doing their own analytical work (law enforcement, national security stuff; organizing investigations and the like). For that company, the open floor plan seemed to work well: it meant the engineers were frequently interacting with the analysts, seeing the things they were talking about, hearing their frustrations with the software, and so on. Some engineers did find it distracting, but headphones seemed to work, and the rest of us found it exciting and engaging (the analysts' conversations were often fascinating). And it meant that the company had engineers who were perhaps second-to-none in understanding analysts' jobs and how they worked, which made for an agile, efficient company in that space.

Not that I disagree for development. This was not a development company, and that's why I'm no longer there. But for that company, the environment was the correct choice I think.

I'm excited to read a firsthand account of such settings being choices or optional, where the culture formally allocates spaces for each environment to be elected by employees depending on their current place in the pipeline.

Well I can attest to this greatly. Sometimes you need to be in the office, sometimes its important to be able to be face to face with others on your team. However, working from a Jr Security Engineer (where I really need to be in the office - but separated from the constant phone calls and other distractions) to support and system engineer roles where in reality, some people work better and function better in regards to productivity because they can stay focused on one thing and one thing only 'work'. Not driving through a nightmare of traffic to get to and from, going to constant meetings that have the same slides as the other global teams all listening and viewing the same content. When the bottom dollar comes down to the client and the engineer - the engineer facilitates the resolution and the client creates it. The employer is impartial (other than ongoing education and facilitating the trust, until the engineer builds it). This is why many organizations lose clients, because they trust the engineer and therefore employee the engineer or find a legal way to recruit the engineer outside of the NDR and NCA legal documents. It's not just software developers but those who support serious software applications that really need to be permitted to be 'innovative'. If we truly are innovative and productive - our reports compared to peers who should be doing the same will ultimately demonstrate the truth. Furthermore, to allow some to do this and to not allow others promotes a culture of favoritism and mistrust. I enjoy what I do but I feel confident I would be more productive to my team if I was able to utilize the same benefits that they can partake in (hence they are more productive). I can only suppose that management simply has either not realized this or has had a few abuse this, which ultimately can be addressed individually if was the case. Software companies I think are really missing out on true gains in metrics when innovation and productivity are suppressed in favor of coming into an office daily (we are already connected via IM and we already have audio/web conferences sometimes more than once a week). If we are already paid on salary, where is the benefit to the employer? From a business perspective, its a loss to both and a moral/trust issue to those who can, to those who cannot. I believe this creates an atmosphere of inequality.

What say all of you?

I think my company has actually done this right.  Our largest developer team room has 3 developers in it and they are all working on the same project right now.  The rest of the offices are only one or two people.  We also keep several empty offices that anyone can use for as short or as long as they like.  It might be just to make a phone call or it could be to better facilitate a heads down development push.

Source: "Peopleware" book, and of course there is something on Stack Exchange on that: http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/132952/studies-on-how-noise-affects-productivity-of-programmers

I'm sorry but this is still a FAIL. Companies don't get it. Having "offices" where a workers back is totally open and exposed (using a glass wall) is a real issue here.

People don't understand that humans can "sense" a lot of information and energy from their back. Ask anyone that studies energy arts or Feng shui and they will tell you that your back needs to be guarded at all times and always face a wall. The phrase that someone has eyes in back of their head is very true in a sense. 

This design here, although I'm sure meaning well, still conveys a lack of trust from the management in their employees, and is no different then any open office or cubicle design where employees backs face out. These designs are all so management can make sure you aren't web browsing or whatever they are worried you are going to be doing in your cubicle. 

Employees in these environments will still suffer from a type of energy anxiety, cause by not knowing what is happening behind them. Anybody that listens to headphones while they work and has a someone come up behind them and tap them on the shoulder knows what I'm talking about. 

Until companies start giving their employees real closed office environments again, they will continue to foster environments of distraction. The worse offenders are the open work environments where you not only have tons of noise pollution (causing everyone to wear headphones) but even worse are the visual distractions of people crossing and moving in your visual field every 5 minutes. 

In this age of software innovation, it amazes me that we had fallen back to the stone-age in the HR department. It's sad because I like a lot of things I hear coming from these smaller companies, but they still fall short. 

The truth is that Microsoft got it right a long time ago advocating offices, although I believe they have since abandoned that. Designers need to adopt a function over form approach instead of a form over function when building work spaces. Instead they build fancy looking offices to impress investors and such but the employee always suffer because of it.
Should read the book PeopleWare by Lister and DeMacro, especially the chapter "The Furniture Police".

A simple comparison. If open space is so great, why don't more companies encourage their people to work in REALLY open spaces like bus depots, airports, fast food restaurants, shopping mall food courts, or even just riding public transportation? Most of the open space cube farms I've worked in, and particularly those where they included the customer call center reps in the same space as the developers and analysts were certainly at least as noisy and distracting as any of those.

I have only worked in cubes and open space offices, never been somewhere nice enough offer non-managers offices. As much as I don't like cubes, they are FAR better than an open space plan for software development. The open plan is stupid on many many levels. In one company I was at, that transitioned to an open plan, I noticed during the weeks following the switch away from cubes that the non-productive employees got louder and louder as time went on. Meanwhile the prductive people turned further and further inward, tryign to isolate themselves with headphones, ignoring everything around them when they walked into the office, and working as short of hours as they could get away without being noticed. It was a strange experience, especially trying to code in that environment, where marketing people 20 feet away were literally yelling at each other over the din. I found employment elsewhere after a few months and was very clear in my exit interview that the shift was detrimental to the quality of the software. That company shrunk in size and became an ad agency (from a software company) over the next 2 years after I left.
There is no way I can ever work sitting with my back to the door or open walls....

@Keith I read PeopleWare years ago, it's a great book. 

There is just really no excuse for these type of work spaces anymore. When it comes down to it, the suits with the money get to decide how to decorate their "house". 

This is why Microsoft had offices from the get go. Bill Gates was a programmer and understood the value of an office. 

No smart programmer would pick an open workspace or cubicle over an office, period. 

I would also bet the same programmer would give away all "perks", free lunch, etc.. for an office where they could think quietly and do their work efficiently. To many programmers are force to either come in early or stay late just to work in quiet. Or worse, make up work at home because they can't get anything done with all the distractions. 

The fact is, most programmers (and creative thinkers) need BLOCKS of uninterrupted time to be efficient and stay in the zone. These blocks usually run in the neighborhood of 4-5 hours at a time. 

Most offices cannot satisfy these conditions for their programmers, and therefore are really dumb workplaces. They may have the smartest people on the planet working there, but they are crippling their minds with "noise". 

Noise or interference in any system is bad.

Sun Microsystems (now Oracle) had some interesting personal offices that I saw recently when I visited their old Santa Clara offices. They were small, perhaps the size of a train compartment, but were proudly decorated with plants and pictures and all sorts of homey things. Obviously the people there took pride in being there. The doors were sliding glass and 2/3rds of the glass is frosted for privacy. Everything was very quiet and well sound proofed. A nice change from modern open plans.

I am so opposed to cubicles for developers. Developers should be provided a large spacious desk (or a desk that can be a standing desk if desired). I do however support limited open floor plans. I find them to be far more inclusive. They need to be limited. You can't stack a dozen people into a shared space. Also things should be done to reduce some levels of noise such as having short walls to deaden sound for when developers are sitting at their desk.

Further things that are important are meeting areas for people to get up and take long discussions to. Meeting rooms that are available. It's worthless to have meeting rooms that are always full and defeat the purpose.

Finally I feel leadership must lead by example. You cannot be an effective leader if you promote an open office layout and then sit in a private office. That is the epitome of hypocrisy. Yes there needs to be private areas for private discussions such as interviews, employee reviews, and other needs. But leadership in development should not need their own private offices as a "status symbol", this just makes you a pointy haired boss ala Dilbert.

Yeah, I would hate to work in that kind of office. It's literally a panopticon (which was invented to make *prisoners* feel like they were being watched at all times).
The concept of the design is to allow a single watchman to observe (-opticon) all (pan-) inmates of an institution without the inmates being able to tell whether or not they are being watched. Although it is physically impossible for the single watchman to observe all cells at once, the fact that the inmates cannot know when they are being watched means that all inmates must act as though they are watched at all times, effectively controlling their own behaviour constantly.

I'm old. Since starting to program professionally at the age of 12, I've now written programs for longer than most programmers have lived. Eeks! I've worked in single person offices, cubicle farms, single offices person stuffed with six programmers, factory floors, and even closets. At the last company I worked for, I worked from both home, with treadmill and desk workstations, as well as the main office, with an open floor plan. What works best? It depends...

When I wrote the dispatcher that refactored queries then ran them in parallel across multiple servers simultaneously, I worked from home with phone disconnected, blinds closed...even Skype off. I needed total concentration and couldn't tolerate any interruptions.

When I wrote web pages, I worked at the office, so I could both answer others' questions, as well as get a sense of how they were working, whether I could do anything to make them more productive (management by observation if you will). What works best varies from culture to culture as well as person to person, and even for the same person, from need to need.

This remains constant, however: Good programmers want to be good programmers and work towards that aim regardless of their environment. Good companies want to be good companies; they work towards that too. If a company has an open floor plan because they're trying to improve communication, that may be a good company to work with. In another, if everyone has an individual office because they're trying to boost productivity, that may be a good company to work with. 

Only if no one really cares, because no one is trying to do more than the minimum, should you run. For no matter how nice the office view, how pleasant the perqs, or how lucrative the contract, a company without people driven to better themselves and others is a morgue. No incentive can cover that smell of death and decay.

I only lasted another 2 1/2 years.  I now work for a start-up where I work from home 3 days a week, where I get most of my work done.  The other 2 days I go into the office, mostly for meetings.  It is an open space but it works because those 2 days I am actually working with the other departments.  It's been 4 months and works perfectly for me.

I'm surprised there hasn't been more of a discussion of the impact of pair programming on the effectiveness of a particular office layout.

When I'm working by myself, I very much prefer quiet and privacy. Noise and conversations in particular are a significant distraction. Translation: I prefer a private, walled office if I'm working by myself, provided I have ready, electronic access to my teammates.

When I'm pairing with someone, I'm in a near constant state of dialog and am pretty much oblivious to what's going on around me. I also find that pairing and the reliance on TDD and other lean/agile practices lead me to break problems down into small pieces which reduces the amount of information I need to keep in my head and reduces the need for total concentration. Translation: I prefer open space if I'm doing pair programming (which is pretty much all the time these days).

I've fortunately only spent a small part of my career in a cubicle, but it was long enough to convince me that it provides the worst of both worlds, maximizing distractions while minimizing the ability to collaborate.

No one has commented on the poor hearing impaired individuals that can be extremely productive if not put into a bullpen of noise.  I am WAY more productive working from home, but my current company does not allow for this policy.

I simply could not accept a permanent position if it required working in the pictured "offices" unless I could rearrange the furniture so I was looking out the window (e.g., back to the wall). A few others have raised that point as well. I had an on-site contract once where the only available desk had its back to the room; productivity was easily halved by the constant pinging from my lizard brain about possible danger behind me.
